body: @ottobackwards Deconflicted and should be good for review.
I've tried to reproduce this failure but to no avail. It was resolved by simply re-running the Travis build, and I'm pretty confident my changes here wouldn't cause such a failure.
I agree, I don't think that was introduced here.  +1
First off, huge ty @mmiklavc for those great testing steps.  It worked flawlessly, and I was able to confirm that both X-Pack and SSL work as expected as of HEAD of this branch.
Thanks @JonZeolla .  I think everything you mentioned is addressed.  If not, let me know. Thanks for your PR and all the effort in reviewing.
+1, pending travis.  Great job

That's great @JonZeolla! Thanks for taking the extra time to verify this - I had originally anticipated just some release doc review on the ES side, but this is wonderful. Big +1 from me.

We've touched on this before, but this work is yet another reason we might want to take another look at dev docs for testing in the project. Right now we hunt and search across old PR's for test scripts and that's probably time better spent simply keeping a core set of test instructions under version control.
+1 thanks for pulling this together and the upstream work on the features themselves, I will definitely be putting them through their paces =)

Thanks.  Yeah, I started with the release doc review, which is what made me think this would be so straightforward.  =)

You are totally right.  Is there a JIRA for that sort of follow-on?  I really think that your steps should be captured somewhere for the future.

Adding my 2 cents here, but also happy to add these thoughts to a discuss thread if others want it. I think it definitely makes sense to qualify and justify the libraries we pull into Metron. To that end, we also do depend on many libraries that don't have a big community backing. In all cases I'm aware of, those libraries aren't the choice between "existing huge community-backed project and @ottobackwards personal OSS project." They're typically the only solution, or one of only a handful of a niche set of solutions for a particular problem. I think the main discussion point on https://github.com/apache/metron/pull/1219 was that there were other available solutions that solved the problem well without requiring the need for a custom fork. AFA the original PR that introduced the dependency, https://github.com/apache/metron/pull/1175, the only suggestion I would make going forward from a community perspective is to include a simple reason why a dependency has been added, ie "adding this bc there isn't a library that accomplishes this, it's used on multiple projects, etc." Basically, what Otto already described.

TL;DR - I think it's reasonable to request minimal justification for new libraries, and it's something to keep in mind in future PRs. Seems to me this dep is justified as I'm unaware of other alternatives that solve this problem. I am also very much in favor of enabling community members to contribute to, and cross pollinate with, other projects as Otto has done here.
I don't think so, but ping @ottobackwards as he's suggested we do this in the past. I've accidentally  duplicated his Jiras before, so it's worth asking haha :-)

The latest commit adds the Management UI as a Knox service.  I've updated the PR description and testing instructions to include it.  Setup is very similar to the Alerts UI.  I am still working on getting the unit tests passing but it should function correctly.

The latest commit addresses the metron-config unit test failures.  This PR should be ready for review.

Now that the parser split pr has landed, I have had to deconflict and refactor this.  I have moved the syslog parsers into the parsing-common module, as they are designed to be the base of other parsers, similar to grok and the others.  They parse the wrapper not the message.

For example, I could ( and may ) re-write the CEF, ASA and other processors on top of the syslog processors.

```
[ERROR] Failed to execute goal org.apache.maven.plugins:maven-surefire-plugin:2.18:test (integration-tests) on project metron-pcap-backend: Execution integration-tests of goal org.apache.maven.plugins:maven-surefire-plugin:2.18:test failed: The forked VM terminated without properly saying goodbye. VM crash or System.exit called?
```

From the looks of it, the VM just randomly crashed? Could you try closing/reopening this PR to re-run Travis?
This was merged into https://github.com/apache/metron/pull/1275.  Closing.

@nickwallen I tend to agree with @ruffle1986 here. With no unit tests in place, this giant component  requires a lot of mocking before we can even run our first test. Since this is a bug fix to an existing component and not a new feature, I feel it's better to confirm with the manual test steps for now, merge it into master and create a separate ticket for achieving decent test coverage for the entire component.

It's not a unit test, but if it's any consolation, [I do have a test for this functionality in the Cypress migration work I'm doing](https://github.com/sardell/metron/blob/METRON-1648/metron-interface/metron-alerts/cypress/integration/alert-details/alert-status/alert-details.status.e2e-spec.js#L42) (admittedly, it's commented out because of this bug).
+1 That works.  Glad we have a test ready to go.
Wrong Jira in title initially, closing/opening to see if I can get the bot to sync up.
+1 Good catch.
Here's the site-book results explicitly linked. It did what I wanted - https://travis-ci.org/apache/metron/jobs/470680143
When I click in Ambari -> Metron service -> Quick Links -> any of the links, it does not get redirected to the Knox gateway. Does this need to be fixed as well?

On the dependency topic...

I am good with depending on simple-syslog assuming there are no other alternatives.  I just want to be sure we're applying the same standards across the project when we look at dependencies.

I do agree that we should provide some minimal justification for new dependencies as @mmiklavc suggested. Going forward, if I introduce a new dependency, I will probably include something like... "Heads up.  There is a new dependency X. I looked at these 3 alternatives with these pros and cons.  I chose X because...".

 And just to be clear, I am not saying that anything wrong was done on #1175.  This is a good contribution to the project.

1. Can you talk about the rewrite rules at all? What are they currently doing and when would someone need to modify those files?

There is not much to say about this because there isn't any significant rewriting going on.  Knox is simply forwarding the requests as is.  This is the same for all 3 services (Alerts UI, Management UI, and REST) and you'll notice all `rewrite.xml` files are structured the same.  The only requirement I had an issue with is that static assets needs to be prepended with the Knox path.  This was solved by making the base href relative in `index.html`.  I added a comment in the metron-alerts `index.html` file but missed it in metron-config.  I will go back and add that comment.  I cannot think of a scenario where changing a `rewrite.xml` file would be necessary.

2. Can you add any comment on the LDAP config with roles? Maybe a very brief cookie cutter example of how a user's LDAP users and groups will translate into Metron's interpretation of that info.

You're right, we should document how this works.  I will add a section to the README.

Actually, looking at this again, the intention was to depend on the Parsers Storm Uber jar.  I think I should restore that behavior, not depend on metron-parsers.
The only example I can find is the SSO topology that ships with Knox and it's set to 30 seconds.
Ok, I fixed it.  This follows the intention of what is supposed to happen.  The only problem was "parsers" needed to be "parsing".

The recent issue with [METRON-1953](https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/METRON-1953) highlights how this PR would change the behavior.  

Had this PR been merged, the REPL would not have blown-up and failed immediately due to that bug.  An error would have occurred only if the user called the function that requires the missing Kraken dependency.

But is that a good thing?  On the positive side, a dependency that I don't care about does not impact me if I am not using a particular function.  If I am not using the function, why should I have to track down an obscure library like Kraken?

On the other hand, it is nice to fail-fast and immediately know there is a problem.  We would not have uncovered METRON-1953 today had this PR been merged.

So which is better?  I am really undecided at this point.

Just a clarification:

> Verify the LDAP check is working. Navigate to Ambari > Metron > Configs > Security and set Knox Enabled to true. Restart the Metron REST component and it should fail with this error:
> Enabling Metron with Knox requires LDAP authentication.  Please set `Knox Enabled` to true in the Metron Security tab.

Check for `Please set "LDAP Enabled" to true`, not Knox Enabled (we enabled Knox already, still need to enable LDAP). The Ambari REST api restart log output shows as expected.

I have a post-merge comment - I really like this change:

> Remove the logout click action in the afterEach hook per the Cypress team's recommendation. While we had to do this to clean up state when the tests were run in protractor, it's unnecessary in Cypress and can cause errors if a test is reloaded before the afterEach executes or loaded before the page reload is complete.

I've used this pattern for integration testing before and it makes repeat runs more reliable, ie by cleaning up before the tests run, if you cancel prior to tests finishing you are still able to re-run without worrying about old state. Also, if you run into a test failure, now you have data post-test run that you can dig into and investigate without modifying your test infrastructure ad-hoc.

Thank you for the fix @merrimanr !

@nickwallen Did you have any thoughts on this question from the description?

> Do we update the Geo DB default URL to point to the updated DB? I'm strongly inclined to do so, but held off pending this PR being discussed. Users should just have to update to the latest from the MaxMind site if this is changed.

The more backwards compatible way, after looking at this again, could also set the default to the be new URL and then fallback to the current (outdated) URL if that file isn't present. At that point the ordering for plain Geo would be

1. User defined URL as seen in global config
2. New default URL
3. Old (current) default URL.

Just going back through your description again to make sure I didn't miss anything else.

> @justinleet Do we want to rename this file and tell users they'll have to use the new version? I don't know how widely used it is.

Yes, I think we should rename this so that it matches it's enhanced functionality.  It now loads both the Geo and the ASN database from Maxmind. So maybe...  `s/geo_enrichment_load.sh/maxmind_enrichment_load.sh`?

> @justinleet I'm inclined to update the Upgrading.md and just telling users to load the ASN database into HDFS, and update any scripts using geo_enrichment_load.sh to use the new thing, along with updating offline installs to also provide the ASN database. New, online installs will pull down both DBs and load them (e.g. full dev).

Yes, I agree.  We should call this out in the Upgrading.md document.

> @justinleet The more backwards compatible way, after looking at this again, could...

Assuming you are referring to the path in HDFS where the databases are stored, then yes, I agree.  That would ensure backwards compatibility.

@anandsubbu - doc change looks good to me. I was most concerned there may have been something talking about requiring those fields in doc changes in this PR - https://github.com/apache/metron/pull/1246/files but it doesn't look like it. @justinleet can you confirm we didn't miss anything there? I'm +1 by inspection pending Justin's feedback.
lgtm pending Travis, +1 by inspection. Thanks @justinleet
@justinleet this should be ready
